Expectation1: Fix bugs and troubleshoot issues reported by users or QA
Situation1: A minor UI glitch occasionally shows up but has an easy workaround
Expectation2: Leading the daily prayers in the mosque
Situation2: A large gathering has assembled for a special remembrance, and no one else present is authorized to lead.
Story: I stared at the bug report blinking on my screen, the QA’s message marked urgent. The UI glitch wasn’t catastrophic, but it was embarrassing, and users were already grumbling in the forum. I knew I could patch it in under an hour if I started now. My phone buzzed—another reminder that the mosque was filling up for the special remembrance. I was the only authorized imam present today, and the community expected me to lead the prayer. I could already picture the rows of worshippers, waiting, trusting I would be there. My manager’s last email echoed in my mind: “We need this fixed before the next release.” But the mosque committee had also stressed the importance of today’s gathering, and I knew how much it meant to everyone. My hands hovered over the keyboard, heart pounding, torn between the silent pressure of code and the living, breathing expectation of my community.
